node.title: Sydney removalists sentenced over COVID trip days before family tragedy
node.alt: Two men wearing face masks and hoods walking down a street.
node.description: The three men were en route to the Central West when one of their COVID tests came back positive. Days later, the mother of two of the men died of the virus.
node.content:
["Three removalists who broke the Sydney lockdown and travelled to the New South Wales\u00a0Central West while infectious with COVID-19\u00a0have been convicted and fined.", "Maryo Shanki, 21, and 27-year-old twin brothers Ramsin Adil and Roni Shawka\u00a0drove from south-west Sydney to Molong, about 30 kilometres north-west of Orange, in July.", "Days after they were tracked down by health officials and charged by police for breaching public health orders, the mother of two of the men died from coronavirus at her home in Sydney.", "The trio appeared at the Orange Local Court for sentencing today\u00a0after pleading guilty via their solicitor at an earlier court appearance.", "", "
Mother-of-five Saeeda Shuka died at her south-west Sydney home after contracting COVID-19
", "The men have been placed on community corrections orders for 12 months and have each been fined $1,100.", "They have also been ordered to pay $2,000 to cover the cost of cleaning a police car.", "Their solicitor, Greg Goold, told the court the men had been born and raised in a small village in Syria near the Iraqi border and had come to Australia after the rise of ISIS saw them lose their family homes and cars.", "He said they had left their country of birth for their own safety.", "
'Lost in translation'
", "The men worked as removalists out of south-western Sydney and followed a NSW Health directive to get daily tests for COVID.", "But they had already left Sydney for their work trip to Molong, 30 kilometres west of Orange, when one of those tests came back positive.", "They were charged for not following\u00a0public health orders because they did not immediately turn around when police caught up with their truck and instead continued on their journey \u2014\u00a0a charge that carries penalties of up to six months' jail, a fine of $11,000, or both.", "Mr Goold told the court that language barriers had caused a misunderstanding.", "\"In trying to do the right thing, they were the victims of lost in translation,\" he said.", "An affidavit filed by the men's employer and read to the court said the trio\u00a0predominantly spoke Chaldean, with only limited English, \"extended only to directions associated with their work and basic exchanges\".", "
'General deterrence'
", "At the time of the offence, there were no known exposure sites to the virus west of the Blue Mountains\u00a0and travel to the region was strictly prohibited with only a handful of exceptions.", "Magistrate David Day said the large First Nations population and low vaccination rates in the Central West at the time meant the trip had exposed the\u00a0community.", "\"No-one was infected,\" he said.", "Magistrate Day said the \"subsequent unrelated spread of COVID into Western NSW, particularly at Dubbo and Wilcannia, demonstrates what the risk was\".", "He said an outbreak, which could have seen cases needing to be cared for at the Orange Health Service, would have \"compromised\" the hospital's function as the major trauma referral centre in the region.", "While the offending was \"well below mid-range\" and there were a number of mitigating factors, including early guilty pleas, their limited English skills and the twins'\u00a0mother's death, Magistrate Day said a significant penalty was needed to warn others from committing similar acts.", "\"The offending of the three men is essentially identical and if the men had a better grasp of English\u00a0I would have no hesitation in sending them to jail because of the need for general deterrence,\" he said."]
